column1: Airplanes emit CO2 in the process of burning engine fuel to provide a lift force that can overcome the aerodynamic drag created by wind resistance. For this reason
column2: the Icao proposals focus on measures to improve planes’ aerodynamics
column3: lightness and engines.

column1: Under the technical proposals
column2: a stringency option of ‘9’ suggested by the US would reduce overall aircraft emissions by 37.5%
column3: while the ‘7’ setting favoured by the EU would imply a 33% cut. The 4.5% gap is equal to 350m tonnes of CO2
column4: or slightly more than Spain emits every year.

column1: EU officials privately concede that their proposal is “the second most ambitious of the positions put on the table”. But they insist that it is still “quite close to the US one” and that the agreement’s small print on cargo aircraft and categorisations should not be overlooked.
Environmentalists argue that the involvement of the Environmental Protection Agency and an unshackled president Obama in the US has contributed to the relative weakness of the EU’s position.
But insiders in Brussels say that the sheer variety of complex issues still to be agreed – and the amount of aircraft manufacturing countries involved
column2: from Brazil and Ukraine to India and China – make like-for-like comparisons unwise
column3: and stringency factors of ‘10’ impossible.

column1: “There are so many parameters to be decided that it creates a lot of pieces you can move around on a chessboard
column2: ” one EU source told the Guardian.

column1: Europe has proposed a 60 tonne threshold for classifying aircraft
column2: as this could cover 90% of emissions and apply to aircraft of the size of a Boeing 737 or Airbus 320 and above.

column1: But the classification would be further sub-divided between new model types and those in production; jets ferrying 19 people or less
column2: and planes carrying freight instead of passengers. Alternate starting dates of 2020 and 2023 for the benchmark are other options under discussion.

column1: An EU source said: “We need a standard that reflects the state of art of the technology
column2: that is as close as possible to what engineers are capable of doing
column3: without going so high that a number of 60-tonne aircraft types would be put out of the market as that would be environmentally unhelpful
column4: economically detrimental and also quite unfair
column5: as lead-in times for aircraft take about 10 years.”"
